1.36.text: Today I'm going to talk with you about nonsuicidal self injury.

4.89.text: We've heard it's a new diagnosis in the DSM. Is that true? What does that mean?

18.48.text: So like I said today I'm going to talk about nonsuicidal self injury.

22.26.text: That is exactly like what it sounds like.

25.25.text: And we have been talking about this on my channel for years.

28.01.text: We talk about self harm, self injury, whatever you want to call it.

31.50.text: It's when we harm ourselves and hurt ourselves without intending to kill ourselves.

37.03.text: And everybody's been excited, because they're like

39.37.text: 'Oh, it's in the DSM, Kati. You have to talk about it. It's a new diagnosis.'

42.23.text: And everybody's been chatting and commenting. And that is great.

44.60.text: But I want to talk to you about what it actually means that it's in the DSM.

50.15.text: It is actually, and I'm looking down because I have … dun dun dun ... my DSM with me.

56.11.text: It's actually in conditions for further study.

59.34.text: And I just want to read you what it says about this area of the DSM,

64.10.text: so that you understand why I hadn't done a video about this diagnosis.

67.55.text: Because it really isn't a diagnosis.

70.22.text: That doesn't mean it doesn't exist, but it's not a new diagnosis. Okay.

74.44.text: It says "Proposed criteria sets are presented for conditions on which future research is encouraged."

82.66.text: And it actually is kind of frustrating, but I understand

85.26.text: the APA, who makes the DSM, can't force people to do research on things.

90.39.text: Nor do they have the funding to make all sorts of research studies happen.

95.25.text: But they're just proposing these certain diagnosis and criteria,

98.95.text: hoping that more research will be done

100.90.text: so that they feel they can actually put it into the DSM with real sets of diagnostic criteria.

107.10.text: Are you following me? I know that can get kind of convoluted.

110.64.text: But it really just means that 'these are things that we think might be a problem,

113.49.text: and maybe be in the DSM soon. Maybe if research is done, we can conclude something. Yay!'

119.24.text: Right. So that is what it falls under.

122.00.text: And it also says, "These proposed criteria sets are not intended for clinical use."

128.30.text: Meaning I'm not even supposed to use these in my practice.

131.35.text: These are just things pretty much that they're thinking more research should be done on.

140.81.text: It states that in the last year, and I think this criteria definitely needs some work.

146.96.text: You can definitely comment in the comments, and let me know what you think.

149.60.text: But this is just what they have so far.

151.69.text: It says that "In the last year the individual has on 5 or more days

156.27.text: engaged in intentional self inflicted damage to the surface of his or her body."

160.59.text: I do like that they include all sorts of different ways that you can self injure.

164.96.text: A lot of you have said like 'Well what if I just bang my head against the wall?

168.13.text: What if I do this? What if I do that?'

169.57.text: It includes any self injurious behavior when it's not because we have autism

175.68.text: or any other spectrum disorder like that.

178.03.text: It's because we want to injure ourselves

180.05.text: and inflict pain on ourselves without the intention of committing suicide.

183.85.text: That's pretty much what would fall under this.

186.23.text: Some of the other criteria is that you're doing it for one or more of the following reasons:

190.65.text: "To obtain relief from a negative feeling or cognitive state,

196.60.text: to induce a positive feeling state" Like we get that euphoria from cutting ourselves.

200.67.text: And I know that a lot of us, however we self injure ourselves,

204.47.text: you reported to me that it's for some variation of those reasons. Right?

209.06.text: So I think they're kind of on the right path there.

211.37.text: The second portion says "That you have to have at least one of the following"

215.41.text: Self injury is associated with one of these.

219.27.text: "Interpersonal difficulties or negative feelings or thoughts

222.56.text: such as depression, anger, generalized distress, etc.

226.82.text: 2: Prior to engaging in the act, a period of preoccupation with the

231.18.text: intended behavior that is difficult to control."

234.35.text: Like we talk about those self harm urges. Right?

236.29.text: We think about it. We almost plan it. A lot of us have rituals around it.

239.39.text: We spend all this time thinking about it, and it becomes completely out of our control then.

245.19.text: We have to do it. Impulses get so strong we can't stop.

248.73.text: Then the third it says "That we also think about self injury

252.85.text: that occurs frequently even when it's not acted upon."

255.69.text: So it means that you're thinking about it all the time.

257.86.text: So it takes up a lot of our brain space.

260.36.text: Another criteria that I think is really interesting, and something that I'm glad they included.

265.22.text: It says "that this behavior is not socially sanctioned."

268.20.text: It's like not body piercing, tattooing, or part of religious or cultural ritual.

272.55.text: "It's not restricted to picking a scab or nail biting."

275.63.text: Because that would be a completely different diagnosis.

278.11.text: If you want more on that topic, click over here.

281.79.text: They also talk about how we need to separate it out from like trichotillomania, hair pulling,

287.53.text: because that could be injuring ourselves, but that's a different set of diagnostic criteria.

294.23.text: Those are usually because of different reasons.

296.64.text: They also make sure to rule out that these things aren't happening

300.19.text: because we're in a psychotic episodes or we have delirium or substance abuse.

305.98.text: Like we're using a substance that's caused us to think

307.92.text: maybe bugs are under our skin, so we pull on that.

310.98.text: They want to make sure that this has nothing to do with that.

313.29.text: That would be a completely different diagnosis.

316.14.text: Now the most important thing for me as a clinician who actually utilizes the DSM,

320.66.text: regardless of what you think about it.

322.32.text: It's something that I have to reference for insurance purposes,

324.58.text: for any kind of diagnostic purposes.

326.50.text: It's the only thing that's accepted in the United States, and so therefore I have to use it a lot.

331.35.text: And self injury used to only fall under BPD, borderline personality disorder.

337.31.text: If you want to know more about that, you can click over here, check that video out.

340.23.text: There's a lot of criteria associated with that.

342.93.text: It was one of the symptoms of BPD.

346.49.text: Now they're making it, potentially in the future,

350.01.text: they may be making it into its own diagnosis.

352.60.text: And they talk about how it would be separating itself from BPD,

356.90.text: because the cool thing is there has been research done

360.07.text: where they've studied people with BPD and those who self injure.

365.13.text: And they found that although there are instances where it does occur together,

371.61.text: So they're finally realizing what you and I have already known.

374.74.text: That self injurious behavior can happen outside of BPD.

378.74.text: I have many clients with complex PTSD.

381.92.text: I have a video about that, if you want to watch that.

384.28.text: Where they use self injury as a way to deal with that.

387.83.text: I've also had eating disorder patients who have done self injury, different behaviors

393.03.text: and it has nothing to do with borderline personality disorder.

395.55.text: And I'm glad that they're finally seeing that distinction.

398.17.text: So my hope is that they do do more research on this, because we know that it's not just BPD.

404.77.text: It's not just a symptom of that. It should be it's own diagnosis.

408.34.text: But at least it's in the DSM in some capacity. Right? Things are moving forward.

412.46.text: They are recognizing that it is it's own diagnosis.

416.22.text: And I think that that's really the best news.

418.49.text: Because we know that it doesn't only exist in BPD, and now everyone's finally catching up.

423.18.text: And as far as treatment options, you know I've talked about DBT for many moons.

429.90.text: I will link a video here that I've talked about self injury

432.66.text: and the treatment options for it, because there are ways to get better.

435.38.text: You can overcome it. Trust me.

438.05.text: I know it seems really hard and the urges could be really strong.

441.00.text: But I've seen so many people overcome it.

443.72.text: And many of our Kinions have too, so if you have any tips and tricks

447.14.text: that have helped you fight those urges and get into recovery, let us know below.

451.40.text: And if you're new to my channel

452.81.text: or if you're old to my channel and you haven't subscribed, why?

456.46.text: And if you want more information about topics such as these, click here.

459.10.text: And if you want to see what else I'm up to in my regular life,

461.73.text: like filming right now … You might know behind the scenes what's happening.

464.84.text: Click all these icons and you can follow me all over.
